summary_reasoning: The report provides several high-quality syntheses that move beyond boilerplate descriptions. Specifically, it quantifies S&P’s pricing power by comparing historical 'rack rates' (8.1 bps in 2025 vs. 6.25 bps in 2016), providing concrete 3-4% CAGR evidence for its moat. It also offers a decision-relevant competitive read-through, linking 'elongated sales cycles' in S&P’s Market Intelligence segment to a negative outlook for competitor FactSet. The analysis of the ratings moat is company-specific, detailing the necessity of 'Big Three' ratings for cross-border deals and the 'chicken-and-egg' regulatory hurdle of NRSRO designations. While the valuation section relies on standard drivers like 'nominal GDP growth' and 'expense discipline,' the report’s use of specific case studies (e.g., the Petronas switch in the Commodity Insights segment) and quantified pricing data elevates it above a 'Fair' grade. It provides clear mechanisms for the firm's competitive advantages rather than just stating they exist. It falls short of 'Excellent' as the core valuation drivers remain relatively standard and it lacks a truly non-obvious, testable thesis regarding a future shift in business trajectory.

insights_classified.text: S&P raised its January 2025 list price by about 2.5% year over year on corporate bond ratings to 8.10 basis points from 7.90 basis points last year... compared with 6.25 basis points in 2016.
S&P Global is seeing elongated sales cycles and slightly higher cancellations in its Market Intelligence segment. Overall, we view this as a negative sign for narrow-moat-rated FactSet.

A rating from a Big Three firm is critical for a cross-border marketed security... an investor wants to know that a B+ rating for a company in California is similar to a B+ rating for a company in Chile.

Infrequent switches [in Platts] seem more the result of concerns about price assessment volatility or methodology. Such was the case in 2011, when Malaysian state-owned oil company Petronas announced it would switch.
S&P announced it will spin off its mobility division in 2026. While this business is moaty, in our view, we see limited fit with S&P's other segments.

red_flags: Generic DCF drivers (revenue growth and expense discipline)
